SENT.plain: Ischemic stroke is a rare event in young adults
We report on a 24-yr-old pilot with cerebral infarction of undetermined etiology, temporally associated with chain smoking
The patient exhibited dysphasia, stupor (confused consciousness), and right facial-nerve palsy
Computed-tomography revealed a low-density area in the left insular cortex
Cerebroangiography showed severe stenosis in a branch of the left middle cerebral artery
After admission, the patient made a rapid and uneventful recovery within 72 h
MRI showed an area of hyperintensity on T2-weighted images 2 mo after the attack
Based on the hyperintense area on FLAIR (fluid attenuated inversion recovery sequence) images obtained in MRI performed 10 mo after the attack, we diagnosed a cerebral infarction
In the Japan Air Self-Defense Force, cerebral infarction is an aeromedically disqualifying condition
However, in the evaluation 2 mo after the attack, differentiation from reversible ischemic neurological deficit was difficult
We discuss the criteria used for diagnosis and the risk factors for cerebral infarction in young adults, as well as the aeromedical disposition of young pilots
